submission_text: How does a stimulus bill impact the value of the US dollar and if the value of the dollar decreases because of this - does that mean a stimulus is a bad idea? Anything we can do to mitigate this while still helping people struggling because of COVID fallout?
body_parent: This is actually one of my favorite things to talk about not COVID, the US dollar. As another user pointed out, the answer kind of depends on what you mean by weakenbecause you specifically mention the value of the dollar decreasing I assume youre talking about inflation where the prices of goods and services increase over time, thus decreasing the purchasing power of a dollar. 1. Inflation, or the decreasing value of a unit of currency, can actually be a sign of a healthy economy. Economists have different opinions about what, exactly, is the ideal rate of inflation. Most believe an annual inflation rate of 1-3 is reasonable, and while they dont have an official inflation target, the US Federal Reserves unofficial target number is a 2 inflation rate. The reason why is because inflation indicates that people are making and spending money when people spend money, demand in general is increasing and thus prices increase because more people are buying more things. Nowinflation can be unhealthy for an economysee Argentina, with an inflation rate of 35-60 in the past several years. Inflation rates above 4 for a sustained period are indicative of a problem with the stability of both the currency and the economy as a whole. The US is not at risk for currency instability in the same way countries like Argentina are experiencing. Ill explain more about that down below. 2. Deflation an increase of the purchasing power of a unit of currency, on the other hand, is almost always a bad sign for an economy. Two notable times the US economy experienced deflation, or an increasing value of the dollar, were during the Great Depression in the 30s and the Great Recession in the 2000s. You definitely dont want deflation. Many economists are warning that the US dollar is actually at risk of experiencing deflation, and thats not surprising millions of Americans still dont have jobs and thus arent making and subsequently spending as much, many are choosing to stay home for safety, and many businesses are closed or have reduced hours and are making less money. Though the US dollar isnt currently experiencing deflation, its closer than many economists and advisers are comfortable with the current rate is 1.18 which is a decent amount below the usual target. 3. Now, some things of note inflation and deflation arent CAUSES of economic events, theyre OUTCOMES. For instance people dont spend money because inflation is high, inflation is high because consumers are spending more than the previous year. The reverse is true of deflation. So inflation rate is one of a handful of ECONOMIC INDICATORS that give us a general idea of how the economy is doing overall. 4. But lets talk about the US dollar specifically. The US dollar is whats called a fiat currency its not tied to any particular physical resource ie gold, silver. I could write a book about why the USD not being pegged to any sort of resource-based standard is a good thing, but thats not the point of this comment. All you need to know is, that makes it easier for Federal Reserve policy to influence the dollar. There are a lot of reasons why the US dollar is unlikely to experience any period of dramatic instability. The US economy is somewhat stable, there are many industries that are operating as efficiently as they were last year or better IE logistics, broadbandtelecom, and many of the industries that are taking a huge hit IE service and retail havent collapsed because of economic reasons, COVID is an outside factor thats causing the problem and once its solved many industries will eventually resume normal functionality though it still might take a couple years to recover. Which leads us to 5. How is the dollar impacted by federal economic policy. There are many ways the federal government can influence inflation and the overall economy. Another commenter mentioned the 1T infusion of cash into the stock market that happened this summer. This, and similar strategies referred to as quantitative easing, are best used when the economy is experiencing trouble at the industry level if a certain kind of industry is doing bad and its threatening to disrupt the economy, the Federal Reserve may temporarily purchase a large number of stocks andor bonds to artificially stabilize the market. This is usually best utilized as a last resort measure in response to an extreme and rapid decline in stock prices. Thats part of the problem. The other problem in the US is that consumers have way less purchasing power. Many people have lost jobs, are working fewer hours, or are just flat-out earning less. The one and only solution to this is a DIRECT STIMULUS which is whats being discussed in congress right now. Thats what youre asking about now, too. A direct stimulus is the best and most efficient way to infuse cash into a stagnant economy when unemployment is high. 6. FINALLY, THE ANSWER short answer, no-a decreasing value of the dollar is not a bad thing. The US economy is experiencing a period of lower inflation. This means the economy is not growing at a fast enough rate. The reason why is because people arent spending money. People are spending less in 2020 vs last year because theyre MAKING lesscant spend money you dont have. A direct stimulus gives people money to spend, which helps stabilize the US economy and keep it afloat. And in this instance, like another commenter mentioned, the direct stimulus is actually a tax advance. The government isnt just printing money to give to us, its redistributing money that already exists to the place where its most likely to go back into the economy directly into consumers pockets. So if youre worried a stimulus is going to cause inflationthats actually the point. A small amount of inflation is a good thing!

The FCC eliminated the policy in 1987 and removed the rule that implemented the policy from the Federal Register in August 2011.  What would the benefits and costs be if the FCC  US were to establish this rule for media companies once again? Would or could this possibly address the issues at hand?
body_parent: I don't advocate regulating internet speech, but the fairness doctrine has no benefit in the world of internet focused media without that aspect. Worth starting here  Because obscenity is not protected by the First Amendment, it is prohibited on cable, satellite and broadcast TV and radio. However, the same rules for indecency and profanity do not apply to cable, satellite TV and satellite radio because they are subscription services. The FCC does not regulate internet speech, or that of Satellite broadcasts. The costs incurred would be incredibly high to regulate, and even higher to enforce, maybe even impossible. The fairness doctrine was established in 1949, and served it's purpose when communication was expensive, and people were only listening on radio  TV - something that anyone w a transmitter has the ability to broadcast to. It's no longer relevant in the internet age - or at least no longer enforceable. This would require 100 of the websites on the internet to be examined on an ongoing basis, scanned for all the same rules that apply as broadcast television, and regulated accordingly. Completely ignoring the political implications of such a clamp down, there are 300 hours of video added to YouTube per minute that would need to be screened for fairness, not including every post that was added to Facebook. Google can't keep up with it at the pace something spreads virally, I have no confidence that a public endeavor could do better. I'm not even sure how YouTube alone could be handled, ignoring every other site on the internet. That would mean 300 60  18,000 people listening and determining if 1 there's a political bias 2 whether there's an opposite viewpoint. The other side of this would be hardware logistics required for enforcement. Every ISP would then need to be able to segment traffic based on location - the internet is inherently an international commodity, with some big caveats  China blocking major search hubs for example. A system would need to be devised for availability of traffic based on an agreed upon algorithm in relation to fairness in real time. Billions in infrastructure changes? Trillions? There would also be a huge shakeup in the cost of doing business on the internet as well as how startups work, grow, and thrive in that environment. Do adult sites get a pass? Does that mean that a blogger has to post 50 of their content as an opposing view? Many many unanswered questions. Costs very high. Benefit is cloudy. I'm not sure it's even possible to enforce without full violation of several amendments.

submission_text: It used to be that the state had a monopoly on mass violence. Conflicts between individual citizens could result in a few deaths or injuries, but casualty figures pretty much scaled linearly with the number of people involved. To inflict mass casualties required involvement of the state, with its huge resources and logistical expertise. This requirement often though, not always acted as a safeguard against random acts of mass violence. But in the modern world, advances in technology have placed mass violence in the hands of the individual citizens. The potential number of casualties per perpetrator has risen dramatically with the advent of IEDs ANFO bombs and automatic assault weapons America was plunged into this reality with the Oklahoma City bombing That was followed by 911 and now we've got the Boston Marathon bombings. In between, there have been mass shooting incidents where a one or two perpetrators have been able to claim the lives of dozens of victims. I think it's safe to assume the march of technology cannot be halted. The information and experience needed to create simple weapons that produce mass casualties is only getting more widespread. Just today, there was a news report that the 3D-printed handgun is now a reality So, if we want to limit these incidents of violence, we're going to have to deal with the individuals who perpetrate them, not the tools they use to wreak their havoc. The question is, how do we do that? I've heard people argue that a lot of these incidents come down to a mental health problem, and reforming our mental health system is a key factor in prevention. I'm sure there's some truth to that, but it can't be the whole story. Some of these crimes are politically motivated. Political bombings in Northern Ireland, Israel and Spain were commonplace for decades, but they seem to have been largely resolved. How did those countries deal with the problem? I've heard other arguments amounting to an acceptance that there will always be evil-doers, so limiting civil liberties is the only way to prevent these incidents in the future. But there are plenty of countries that haven't limited civil liberties and they're not suffering from frequent attacks, so again, this seems not to be a definitive answer. The upshot is, access to the means of causing mass violence is basically universal, but the violence itself is not. What can the places that are suffering from such violence learn from the places that aren't? TLDR The world is getting smaller and destructive technology is getting more accessible. What do we need to change so we can all live together peacefully? ----- EDIT Some responses indicate that people think this post is about or advocating gun control, so let me clarify this in a way that I hope Second Amendment advocates of which I am one will understand. Let's take it as a given that guns don't kill people people kill people. Assume the same holds for bombs and IEDs. All of those weapons, depending on their power, allow for a single attacker to cause multiple casualties, and all have become easie to acquirebuild in recent years. Signs indicate that trend will continue and any efforts to reverse it are futile. OK? No taking of guns. No effective regulation of pressure cookers or fertilizer. We're all able to arm ourselves, whether or not we intend to. Now, if we accept all that, how do we reduce incidents of mass violence caused by one or two individuals? body_parent: The draft order does several different things 1. Instruct the FCC to issue new regulations relating to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act I'll return to this. 2. Potentially restrict federal agencies from advertising on platforms judged to engage in viewpoint-based speech restrictions the section heading here refers to a prohibition but the text actually just requests a review Insofar as this is actually just a review, there's no real legal problem. 3. Create a report on bias in online platforms and recommend that the FTC consider appropriate action Again, this doesn't actually do anything interesting although it could be the first step towards something else. 4. Establish a working group with state attorneys general on online bias Again, this doesn't really do anything. The action here is really on the first item. The other three could end up going in a variety of directions but don't presently represent clear proposals to do anything with interesting legal implications. So, let's focus on 1 which requires understanding what Section 230 does and why. Keep in mind that Section 230 is a statute, so it cannot be modified by an executive order. At most, an executive order can change within reason how executive agencies interpret a statute. Section 230 immunity comes from 47 U.S. Code Section 230c1 This reads in full No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider. That probably sounds rather boring, but it's often been called the twenty-six words that created the internet To understand why, we have to take a bit of a trip through libel and defamation law. Eugene Volokh just published an excellent summary on this topic, so I'll refer you there for a more detailed account. In brief, prior to Section 230, there was a dispute about the level of responsibility held by an online platform for what someone else writes on said platform. That is, if I post something defamatory on Reddit, then what is Reddit's responsibility for that content? If Reddit is a publisher like, say, a newspaper, then Reddit is responsible for the content and you can sue Reddit if I defame you via Reddit. If, on the other hand, Reddit is merely a distributor or platform then they are not liable for what I say just because they happen to have transmitted it. You can think of this as the difference between a newspaper and a news stand. If a newspaper publishes a letter to the editor from some random citizen, they assume some responsibility for its content including defamatory content because they vetted the letter and chose to publish it. On the other hand, the owner of the news stand that sells the newspaper probably didn't even read it, and isn't held responsible for the content. The trucker that brings the newspaper from the printer to the news stand is even less responsible -- it would seem totally unreasonable to hold them liable here. So, is a website more like the newspaper, the news stand, or the trucker? Before the Communications Decency Act, courts took the position that a website that did not exercise any editorial control was like a news stand -- not responsible for the content. However, in Stratton Oakmont v. Prodigy Services the court held that a site that exercised any editorial control thereby became a publisher. So, just censoring profanity or other fairly trivial content policies transformed you into a publisher, who was liable for defamation like a newspaper would be. For an internet company, liability for defamation would be a business-ending catastrophe. Reddit, Facebook, Twitter none of these actually existed yet of course would be exposed to a lawsuit any time anyone uses their site to defame someone else which happens constantly. They would be rapidly bankrupted. Thus, the pre-CDA regime created a perverse incentive for companies not to moderate content at all so that they would be treated as distributors rather than publishers. Censor our curse words to make you're site kid-friendly? Now you're liable for everything on your site. Let people post horrifying torture porn without interfering? No liability. It's a simple business decision to just allow people to do whatever they want you still have to remove illegal content on request but that's a different issue. So, Congress included Section 230 in the CDA for the purpose of making it safe for internet companies to moderate content without thereby exposing themselves to liability for what their users did. In fact, the legal treatment was basically to give internet companies the level of immunity enjoyed by the trucker rather than the news stand in the example above. There's a debate about whether this went too far in limiting internet company liability, but the alternative was to make it impossible for companies to moderate anything. Circling back around, certain conservatives believe that Facebook, Twitter, etc. have abused this regime by censoring speech on a political basis and that this ought to transform them into publishers who are then liable for third party content on their sites like a newspaper would be. Obviously, the President cannot change a law passed by Congress unilaterally, and that applies to the CDA. The Executive Order envisions I think this part gets too in the weeds to be interesting but see my followup if you want to read more, however, a way of reinterpreting Section 230 such that platforms that remove content for certain reasons including alleged political bias would forfeit their Section 230 immunity. This would be the death penalty for internet companies -- even Facebook or Google's resources could not possibly survive the onslaught of defamation suits, so they would have to cave and stop moderating content. That may sound like a big deal, but it's basically toothless. The proposal is to do this via FCC rule-making, but Section 230 defends internet companies against private lawsuits. If you attempt to sue Facebook for some content posted by a user, then Section 230 allows Facebook to get that lawsuit immediately dismissed. The FCC is not part of that process, and an executive order doesn't get to change how courts interpret the law if you're into this stuff, it's worth noting an interesting contrast in what Trump appears to be hoping for here and his administration's attitude towards Chevron deference but maybe no one else finds that amusing. So, is there a precedent? Absolutely. Trump wants to go back to the pre-CDA regime governing the internet. Is it workable legally? No, not really. In this game of rock-paper-scissors, a statute beats an executive order. Is this a big deal? Yes, but for a different reason. I would guess that every lawyer and lobbyist for a tech company is currently quietly panicking, not because this executive order is itself threatening but because it might be the first shot in a broader war to change the legal regime governing the internet. TLDR The order doesn't actually do anything, but laws sure are interesting. Edit See my follow up post on the legal theory used in the Executive Order to reinterpret Section 230.

Georgia to argue that the people, in establishing the Constitution, necessarily subjected the State of Georgia to the jurisdiction of the federal courts in exchange for accomplishing the six broad goals listed in the Constitutions Preamble. x200B The Preamble appears to have had a more significant influence outside of judicial opinions in statements from the leaders of the political branches of government, often factoring in various debates during the early history of the nation. For instance, during the debates in the First Congress over the constitutionality of the Bank of the United States, congressional leaders, like Elbridge Gerry of the Massachusetts, quoted the Preamble to note the broad objects for which the Constitution was established and to justify the establishment of a national bank to promote the general welfare.14 And the Preamble featured in early congressional debates over the role of the new government in foreign affairs. For example, during the Tenth Congress, Henry Southard of New Jersey cited the Preamble in arguing in favor of Congress arming and equipping the militia of the United States, recognizing that it was the object of the establishment of the federal government to provide for the common defence against foreign enemies. 15 Perhaps one of the most famous references to the Preamble in the halls of Congress came in a speech of Senator Daniel Webster in the midst of the nullification debates of the 1830s, wherein he quoted the Preamble to argue that the Constitution was perpetual and immortal, establishing a union which shall last through all time. 16 While the Preamble may have had particular relevance to a number of isolated questions before the Congress in the Nations early years, Presidents and congressional leaders have more generally relied on the Preambles laudatory phrases in exploring the broader import of the Constitution and the general purposes of American government. For instance, President James Monroe referred to the Preamble as the Key of the Constitution, 17 and in his inaugural address, President John Quincy Adams described the first words of the Constitution as declaring the purposes for which the government should be invariably and sacredly devoted. 18 Echoing these themes in his own first inaugural address, President Abraham Lincoln invoked the Preambles perfect union language to note the importance of national unity as the country faced the brink of civil war. 19 In the midst of another constitutional crisisR12that which arose in 1937 amid clashes over the constitutionality of the New DealR12 President Franklin Roosevelt stated the need to read and reread the preamble of the Constitution, as its words suggested that the document could be used as an instrument of progress, and not as a device for prevention of action. 20 Decades later, Representative Barbara Jordan, the first African-American woman elected to the House of Representatives from the South, quoted the Preamble in a statement before the House Judiciary Committee as it considered the Articles of Impeachment for President Richard Nixon.21 In that statement, she noted that through the process of amendment, interpretation, and court decision she had been included in We, the people and was now serving as an inquisitor aiming to preserve the goals of the Constitution. x200B x200B

You're waiting for news on when the orbiter, well, goes into a stable orbit. However, it was not to be. On September 23, 1999, the planned orbital insertion maneuver went awry and NASA lost radio contact. It seems that it went too close to the planet, and paid the price. But why? An investigation would later reveal that the fault was not in the orbiter but in the ground software used to calculate the descent. A portion of the software made by Lockheed Martin calculated things in United States Customary Units, also known as Imperial Units1. However, its Software Interface Specification said that it worked in SI units, also known as Metric Units2. This is bad because the NASA program using this data expected those SI units. This sounds like a minor error, but in reality, is as bad of a translation and cultural exchange as if an Australian called their American friends the C-word, or if Italians were forced to eat Taco Bell's Mexican Pizza. A simple unit mismatch caused the destruction of a 327.6 million project, which is more like 500 million in today's money3. This of course raises the question why doesn't the US use the metric system for everything?  Why does the US Have its Own Units Anyway? Well, technically, they're not exclusive to the US Canada and the UK still use Imperial Measurements to some degree. But only the US sticks to these non-metric units for everything from rulers to highways. To understand why, it's important to understand why US customary units exist in the first place. As far as I understand, there are a few main reasons why the US doesn't use metric 1. It industrialized relatively early in history. Standards of weights and measures are really important for making precise machinery and conducting scientific experiments. Therefore, the nation needed to adopt a standard that was widely used at the time. Which leads me to... 2. The British, the nation and empire at the center of the Industrial Revolution, were still using imperial units. It stands to reason that if you wanted compatibility in engineering and science with them, you would adopt their units. The 1824 Weights and Measures Act in the Uk wiped the slate clean for measurement systems and established imperial units, so why not base things off of them? 3. Religion. Seriously. In Ohio there was an organization that opposed adopting the metric system because they saw the French Revolution as atheistic. Apparently, the state has been crazy for a very long time. I'm sure there were other reasons behind the US Customary system, so please feel free to tell me in the comments. However, that still begs the question  Why doesn't the US Switch to Metric? I mean, basically every other country on earth has done it. Even the US is slowly inching towards such a reform with the Metric Conversion Act I am also in favor of such a change. However, do seem to be a few reasons for opposition 1. The US is a big place, and it would be incredibly expensive to replace all the signage on the highway system to be metric in a short timeframe. 2. The hybrid system is basically fine already. The disaster with the Mars Climate Orbiter was just a mistake, and coexistence generally works out. 3. The Metric System might not be better than Customary for all use cases. This article notes that customary has units that fit human scale, like a cup of liquid that you would actually drink in one sitting, and the foot which metric has no defined equivalent. In this sense, customary might be more intuitive and better in certain areas such as woodworking. Again, if you have other reasons to support the Customary system or are against a full conversion to metric, please put your reasons down in the comments. submission_text: I'm an Indian and there has been a debate about whether we should replace our parliamentary form of government with a presidential form with a directly elected head. The most common argument against it has been the over-centralization of power in one individual. I am curious as to what the American populace thinks of it and how well has it fared for you.
body_parent: I don't particularly care for parliamentary government because of its nasty tendency to collapse, especially when the margins are tight. Currently, our House of Representatives has 221 Democrats and 212 Republicans, with two vacancies, which is the slimmest majority a party has had in decades. The Democratic Party is, in our terms, a Big Tent party, which means it has a very broad ideological spectrum. There are social democrats in the same party as some pretty right wing people, which can cause a lot of problems. If we had a parliamentary system, only six conservative Democrats could announce they were pulling support from Speaker Pelosi, and then she would be forced from office, possibly causing a snap election. There's also the fact that I don't care for indirectly-elected leadership, which is what a Prime Minister is. Presidents of parliamentary republics are weak executives, figureheads who just sign laws without exercising much real authority. The power lies in the Prime Minister, who is themselves usually chosen by party elites. Case in point, Liz Truss, the UK's new PM, was given her position by a leadership election of some 180,000 dues paying members of the Conservative Party, and now she governs the other 67,000,000 people who had no say in the matter. In fact, the parties and their lists have too much power in general under the parliamentary system, in my opinion. There are serious problems with the strong executive presidency, of course. There's too much legal shielding for presidents, and the bureaucracy of the executive branch has gotten a bit too large with the legislature mostly content to leave policy in the hands of executive orders which can easily be undone by the next president when they take office. That said, I like the stability and continuity that our system provides. Elections are neatly timed, coalitions mostly hold for the duration of each Congress, and I have a direct say in who actually governs me. I think I'd like to stick with it.

submission_text: Puerto Rico is in a financial wreck at the moment, but even without that burden many people have questioned whether a bill to have Puerto Rico turned into a state could even so much as leave the Subcommittee on Indian, Insular and Alaska Native Affairs to which the bills about Puerto Rican statehood get referred, let alone leave that committee and get put up for a vote before the Republican-dominated Congress. It's not the fault of the specific party, it's simply how political parties operate in general Puerto Rico would probably be a blue state, and political parties generally don't vote in favor of things that would make them lose power. I've begun to wonder recently, though, if Puerto Rican statehood could be made more likely from a political standpoint if it were made more bipartisan. How so? Well, one solution is to handle this the way we did during the most divisive time in US history by simultaneously going through the statehood process with another state that would politically counteract it. This is where the Mariana Islands come in. First, some background, including a history lesson The Mariana Islands are an island chain that is politically split into two territories Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. These two territories used to be a single colony under Spain until the US took Guam as spoils of the Spanish-American War and gave the rest of the islands now the Northern Marianas to Germany who didn't even fight in the war, the US simply did so because they heard Germany was negotiating with Spain for those islands by the time the US won that war. The Northern Marianas changed hands repeatedly before becoming a US territory. Some referendums were had during the 1960's or so to see if the islands wanted reunification, but Guam refused for reasons that are, in my opinion, no longer really politically relevant allegations that the Northern Marianas were spying or working with the Japanese during World War II, or fears that they would receive higher taxes, which I believe nowadays has been guaranteed will not happen to them if they enter political union, via 48 U.S.C. 1844 Economically, the Northern Marianas and Guam both rely on Japanese tourism and the US military for much of their economy. Both of these could be streamlined and improved by reunifying into a single territory or commonwealth, and 48 U.S.C. 1844 effectively guarantees them the best of both worlds should they reunify this means, for example, that Guam could fall under the CNMI Covenant, which the population prefers the idea of over Guam's Organic Act. The tourism industry in particular could benefit from statehood, given that it would increase the awareness of the islands in the mainland US. Politically, a reunified Marianas territory or commonwealth turning into a state would make for a PERFECT senatorial counterbalance to Puerto Rico becoming a state, because Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands both have a strong history of voting for the Republican party, and, in the case of the Northern Mariana Islands, the leading opposing party to the Republicans aren't democrats, but rather a different conservative party. The Mariana Islands are as red as Puerto Rico is blue, and it is because of this idea that I've led myself to believe that having binding statehood referendums for both if reunification happens of the commonwealths could lead to a statehood bill getting bipartisan support, and debates that don't simply come down to which party would get a Senate advantage. I assume I am overlooking things here, which is why I submitted the idea here to ask what the biggest pragmatic problems with this idea are, or other feedback. To put it simply, would this be a viable idea?

Puerto Rico would certainly carry more weight, and if your assumptions about political leanings are true I have no idea about Puerto Rican politics, then I seriously doubt that the GOP would consider that a good trade off.
